questions.text: For a patient presenting with gradual, painless diminution of vision, the differential diagnosis would not include _________.
questions.solution:
Methyl alcohol amblyopia causes sudden painless diminution of vision.

It is a toxic neuropathy of the optic nerve.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?
questions.solution:
The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellens chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points. Snellens chart is used for Visual acuity assesment.

In snellens chart the alphabets decrease in size as we move from above-downwards and these lines, from above-downwards should be read at 60, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, 5 and 4 m respectively. At these distances, the respective letters subtend a visual angle of 5 minutes. Hence, the largest alphabet that should be read at 60 m subtends a visual angle of 5 minutes in the eye.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the OPD for an eye exam. He is having difficulty reading newspapers but has no problem watching television.  At what distance would you ask him to read a Jaeger's chart from?
questions.solution:
Jaeger’s chart is held at a distance of 35 cm away from the patient.

It is used to measure near vision. The smallest letter is designated as N5 or J1 and the largest as N48. Snellen's near vision chart can also be used.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for a recent eye injury. The result of his Placido disc test is shown below. What is the correct interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given Placido’s disc test result indicates a normal corneal surface.

This test is used to detect an abnormal corneal surface. Irregularities of the corneal surface cause distortion of the circles.

Distortion of the circle is seen in keratoconus, keratoglobus, corneal ulcer, and corneal abrasion.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following finding in his eye. Fluorescein staining is done and the eye is observed under cobalt blue light. What would be seen?
questions.solution: The image shows a corneal ulcer. The ulcer takes the stain and appears brilliant green, and when examined under cobalt blue light, it appears opaque green.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man, known case of diabetes mellitus, presented with headache and eye pain. He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Visual field-testing indicates peripheral vision loss.  The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument during his examination of this patient. What is he measuring by using the following instrument?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is the Schiotz tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP).

This patient's complaints of headache, eye pain, difficulty in adapting to darkness, and examination findings of peripheral vision loss with increased intraocular pressure, is suggestive of glaucoma.  

Schiotz tonometer is a type of indentation tonometer. The principle behind its use is that the plunger will indent a soft eye more than a hard eye.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: The concept of the procedure was introduced by Goldmann.
It is used to treat after cataract
It is based on the Imbert-Fick law
It is used to investigate glaucoma

questions.solution:
The instrument shown is an applanation tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). 

The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. It is based on Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

P = W/A

The different types are Goldmann tonometer, Perkin’s tonometer, pneumatic tonometer, pulse air tonometer, tono-pen.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for his myopia. He is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on him.
questions.solution:
The above image is of the dynamic contour tonometer such as the Pascal tonometer. The dynamic contour tonometer(Pascal) offers a non-invasive and direct method of intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement with an additional measurement of the ocular pulse amplitude. This type of tonometer is unaffected by the corneal thickness and it is the tonometer of choice in post-Lasik patients.

Option A: Pachymetry is used to measure the corneal thickness. 
The below image is of pachymetry.

 

Option C: Auto Refractotemetry is a computerized refractometer that is used to find out the error of refraction. This gives rapid information about the kind of refractive error in terms of sphere, cylinder with axis and inter pupillary distance.

Option D: A-Scan ultrasonography is a useful diagnostic tool for intraocular evaluation especially in the setting of opaque media. The report of the A scan is displayed as a unidimensional display of spikes along a baseline where the distance between the spikes gives the indirect measurement of the tissues. A-scan is used to measure

  • The axial length of the eyeball for Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation
  • Anterior chamber depth
  • Thickness of intraocular mass.

questions.text: You can use any of the following to estimate the visual field of a patient except:
questions.solution:
Optical coherence tomography is not used to estimate the visual field. It is a non-invasive imaging technique to visualize cross-sections of the retina.

Perimetry is used to estimate the visual field.

Types:

questions.text: Which among the following phases indicate complete filling of the retinal arterioles and capillaries on fundus fluorescein angiography?
questions.solution:
Complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries is seen in the arterio-venous phase.

In FFA, sodium fluorescein dye is injected into the antecubital vein. A fundus camera is then used to take photographs:

  • 1st picture- after 5 seconds, then every second for 20 seconds, every 3–5 seconds for the next 1 minute
  • Last picture- after 10 minutes
    • Pre-arterial phase- choroidal circulation is filling
    • Arterial phase- start filling of retinal arteriole till its completely filled
    • Arterio-venous phase- complete filling of retinal arterioles and capillaries followed by laminar filling of veins
    • Venous filling- arterioles are emptying and veins are filling

Indications for fundus fluorescein angiography:

  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Vascular occlusion
  • Eale’s disease
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Cystoid macular edema

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with diabetes presents with complaints of dark floating spots and flashes of light in her left eye. Optical coherence tomography of the left eye is given in the image below. Identify the pathology.
questions.solution:
The image shows vitreomacular traction with detached posterior vitreous membrane and foveal traction. 

OCT images:

1. Normal OCT

 

2. Vitreomacular traction- The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as indicated by the arrow. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion may also be seen at the site of traction.

 

3. Vitreomacular adhesion- posterior vitreous detachment but no macular or foveal traction. The retinal morphology is normal.

 

4. Macular hole - a partial or full-thickness retinal defect is seen.

A full-thickness macular hole is seen in the image below.

 

5. Central serous retinopathy- fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment. 

 

6. Cystoid macular edema - loss of foveal depression with cystoid spaces in the retina.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female, who is a known case of type 2 diabetes, is undergoing serial electroretinograms to monitor disease progression. The following finding was obtained from her recent test. What does the wave marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.solution:
The wave marked is the "B" wave. It represents the activity of bipolar cells.

Electroretinogram (ERG) is used to detect the functional abnormality of the outer retina up to the bipolar cells.

questions.text: You would classify the electrooculography (EOG) of a patient as subnormal if the Arden ratio is less than ______.
questions.solution:
In electrooculography (EOG), the subnormal curve is <150.

EOG is based on the measurement of the resting membrane potential of the eye between the cornea (+) and the back of the eye (-). Interpretation is based on the Arden ratio.

Arden Ratio = Max height of light peak/Min height of dark trough × 100

  • Normal curve: 185 or above
  • Subnormal curve: <150
  • Flat curve: <125

questions.text: You can use 'A' scan for all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Assessment of vitreous hemorrhage is done by "B" scan.

Both 'A' and 'B' scans are types of ultrasound (USG) scans.

A scan (time amplitude) B scan (intensity modulation)
It produces a unidimensional image and echoes are plotted as spikes. It produces a two-dimensional dotted section of the eyeball.

Uses:

  • Axial length
  • Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation: Biometry
  • Anterior chamber depth
  • The thickness of intraocular mass

Uses:

  • Assessment of the posterior segment in opaque media
  • Study of intraocular tumors
  • Localization of intraocular and intra-orbital foreign bodies

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the instrument in the image?

choices.text: It is used to test macular function
It is used to measure vertical, horizontal tropias, and phorias
It cannot be used to  measure cyclodeviation
It is based on diplopic projection

questions.solution:
The image shows a Maddox rod.

Cyclodeviation is measured with the double Maddox rod test.

The Maddox rod test uses a specially constructed device consisting of a series of parallel cylinders that converts a point source of light into a line image.

It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclodeviations.

questions.text: A woman came to the OPD due to blurring of vision while working on her laptop. Retinoscopy was performed at 1 m without cycloplegia. The red reflex moves in the same direction as the retinoscope. Which of the following refractive errors is not possible in this patient?
questions.solution: A patient with 1 D myopia would exhibit no movement of red reflex when retinoscopy is done from a distance of 1m without cycloplegia.

questions.text: The following image indicates:
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy.

The central image shows the primary position of gaze where the patient's left eye is deviated down and out with ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements in other positions, it can be seen that adduction and elevation are absent and depression is reduced in the left eye. All of these findings are indicative of oculomotor nerve palsy.

3rd Cranial nerve(oculomotor nerve) palsy presents with: 

  • Ptosis due to weakness of levator palpebrae superioris muscle (LPS)
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position (down and out) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus(6th nerve supply) and superior oblique muscles(4th nerve supply)
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy (involvement of Edinger Westphal parasympathetic supply)
  • Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to ipsilateral paralysis of medial rectus, inferior oblique and inferior rectus .

Option A: Trochlear(4th cranial) nerve palsy presents with superior oblique muscle paralysis.

Clinical findings of trochlear nerve palsy include:

  •  Hypertropia (elevation) in the primary position
  • Extorsion that is greatest in abduction
  • Compensatory head posture with contralateral face turn and head tilt with chin slightly depressed. This position is assumed to avoid Diplopia.
  • Limitation of depression 
  • Normal abduction and elevation.

The below given image depicts 4th cranial nerve palsy.

 

Option B: Lateral rectus palsy is seen in cases of isolated Abducens nerve palsy. These patients present with esotropia/convergent squint in primary position with limitation of abduction on the side of the lesion. This is due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle in the affected eye.

There is also a compensatory head turn towards the side of the lesion to reduce the symptom of Diplopia. The adduction is normal in lateral rectus palsy.

Option C: Internuclear opthalmoplegia occurs following an injury to the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). A unilateral lesion to the MLF leads to the failure of adduction in the ipsilateral eye with a normal abduction of the contralateral eye.

The below given image depicts the pathogenesis of Inter nuclear opthalmoplegia in detail.

questions.text: Photostress test is used to differentiate between:
questions.solution:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between the disease involving the macula and optic nerve.

This test is of particular use in early macular diseases such as central serous retinopathy.

In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again, and the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.

In normal people and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. Whereas, in patients with macular disease the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.
